lines.0: Thou still unravish'd bride of quietness,
lines.1: Thou foster-child of silence and slow time,
lines.2: Sylvan historian, who canst thus express
lines.3: A flowery tale more sweetly than our rhyme:
lines.4: What leaf-fring'd legend haunts about thy shape
lines.5: Of deities or mortals, or of both,
lines.6: In Tempe or the dales of Arcady?
lines.7: What men or gods are these? What maidens loth?
lines.8: What mad pursuit? What struggle to escape?
lines.9: What pipes and timbrels? What wild ecstasy?
lines.11: Heard melodies are sweet, but those unheard
lines.12: Are sweeter; therefore, ye soft pipes, play on;
lines.13: Not to the sensual ear, but, more endear'd,
lines.14: Pipe to the spirit ditties of no tone:
lines.15: Fair youth, beneath the trees, thou canst not leave
lines.16: Thy song, nor ever can those trees be bare;
lines.17: Bold Lover, never, never canst thou kiss,
lines.18: Though winning near the goal yet, do not grieve;
lines.19: She cannot fade, though thou hast not thy bliss,
lines.20: For ever wilt thou love, and she be fair!
lines.22: Ah, happy, happy boughs! that cannot shed
lines.23: Your leaves, nor ever bid the Spring adieu;
lines.25: For ever piping songs for ever new;
lines.26: More happy love! more happy, happy love!
lines.27: For ever warm and still to be enjoy'd,
lines.28: For ever panting, and for ever young;
lines.29: All breathing human passion far above,
lines.30: That leaves a heart high-sorrowful and cloy'd,
lines.31: A burning forehead, and a parching tongue.
lines.33: Who are these coming to the sacrifice?
lines.34: To what green altar, O mysterious priest,
lines.35: Lead'st thou that heifer lowing at the skies,
lines.36: And all her silken flanks with garlands drest?
lines.37: What little town by river or sea shore,
lines.39: Is emptied of this folk, this pious morn?
lines.40: And, little town, thy streets for evermore
lines.41: Will silent be; and not a soul to tell
lines.42: Why thou art desolate, can e'er return.
lines.44: O Attic shape! Fair attitude! with brede
lines.45: Of marble men and maidens overwrought,
lines.46: With forest branches and the trodden weed;
lines.47: Thou, silent form, dost tease us out of thought
lines.49: When old age shall this generation waste,
lines.50: Thou shalt remain, in midst of other woe
lines.51: Than ours, a friend to man, to whom thou say'st,
lines.52: "Beauty is truth, truth beauty,—that is all
lines.53: Ye know on earth, and all ye need to know."

lines.0: My heart aches, and a drowsy numbness pains
lines.1: My sense, as though of hemlock I had drunk,
lines.2: Or emptied some dull opiate to the drains
lines.3: One minute past, and Lethe-wards had sunk:
lines.4: 'Tis not through envy of thy happy lot,
lines.5: But being too happy in thine happiness,—
lines.6: That thou, light-winged Dryad of the trees
lines.8: Of beechen green, and shadows numberless,
lines.9: Singest of summer in full-throated ease.
lines.11: O, for a draught of vintage! that hath been
lines.12: Cool'd a long age in the deep-delved earth,
lines.13: Tasting of Flora and the country green,
lines.14: Dance, and Provençal song, and sunburnt mirth!
lines.15: O for a beaker full of the warm South,
lines.16: Full of the true, the blushful Hippocrene,
lines.17: With beaded bubbles winking at the brim,
lines.19: That I might drink, and leave the world unseen,
lines.20: And with thee fade away into the forest dim:
lines.22: Fade far away, dissolve, and quite forget
lines.23: What thou among the leaves hast never known,
lines.24: The weariness, the fever, and the fret
lines.25: Here, where men sit and hear each other groan;
lines.26: Where palsy shakes a few, sad, last gray hairs,
lines.27: Where youth grows pale, and spectre-thin, and dies;
lines.28: Where but to think is to be full of sorrow
lines.30: Where Beauty cannot keep her lustrous eyes,
lines.31: Or new Love pine at them beyond to-morrow.
lines.33: Away! away! for I will fly to thee,
lines.34: Not charioted by Bacchus and his pards,
lines.35: But on the viewless wings of Poesy,
lines.36: Though the dull brain perplexes and retards:
lines.37: Already with thee! tender is the night,
lines.38: And haply the Queen-Moon is on her throne,
lines.39: Cluster'd around by all her starry Fays;
lines.40: But here there is no light,
lines.41: Save what from heaven is with the breezes blown
lines.42: Through verdurous glooms and winding mossy ways.
lines.44: I cannot see what flowers are at my feet,
lines.45: Nor what soft incense hangs upon the boughs,
lines.46: But, in embalmed darkness, guess each sweet
lines.48: The grass, the thicket, and the fruit-tree wild;
lines.49: White hawthorn, and the pastoral eglantine;
lines.50: Fast fading violets cover'd up in leaves;
lines.52: The coming musk-rose, full of dewy wine,
lines.53: The murmurous haunt of flies on summer eves.
lines.55: Darkling I listen; and, for many a time
lines.56: I have been half in love with easeful Death,
lines.57: Call'd him soft names in many a mused rhyme,
lines.58: To take into the air my quiet breath;
lines.59: Now more than ever seems it rich to die,
lines.60: To cease upon the midnight with no pain,
lines.61: While thou art pouring forth thy soul abroad
lines.63: Still wouldst thou sing, and I have ears in vain—
lines.64: To thy high requiem become a sod.
lines.66: Thou wast not born for death, immortal Bird!
lines.67: No hungry generations tread thee down;
lines.68: The voice I hear this passing night was heard
lines.69: In ancient days by emperor and clown:
lines.70: Perhaps the self-same song that found a path
lines.71: Through the sad heart of Ruth, when, sick for home,
lines.72: She stood in tears amid the alien corn;
lines.74: Charm'd magic casements, opening on the foam
lines.75: Of perilous seas, in faery lands forlorn.
lines.77: Forlorn! the very word is like a bell
lines.78: To toll me back from thee to my sole self!
lines.79: Adieu! the fancy cannot cheat so well
lines.80: As she is fam'd to do, deceiving elf.
lines.81: Adieu! adieu! thy plaintive anthem fades
lines.82: Past the near meadows, over the still stream,
lines.83: Up the hill-side; and now 'tis buried deep
lines.85: Was it a vision, or a waking dream?
lines.86: Fled is that music:—Do I wake or sleep?

lines.0: Two roads diverged in a yellow wood,
lines.1: And sorry I could not travel both
lines.2: And be one traveler, long I stood
lines.3: And looked down one as far as I could
lines.4: To where it bent in the undergrowth;
lines.6: Then took the other, as just as fair,
lines.7: And having perhaps the better claim,
lines.8: Because it was grassy and wanted wear;
lines.9: Though as for that the passing there
lines.10: Had worn them really about the same,
lines.12: And both that morning equally lay
lines.13: In leaves no step had trodden black.
lines.14: Oh, I kept the first for another day!
lines.15: Yet knowing how way leads on to way,
lines.16: I doubted if I should ever come back.
lines.18: I shall be telling this with a sigh
lines.20: Two roads diverged in a wood, and I—
lines.21: I took the one less traveled by,
lines.22: And that has made all the difference.

lines.0: I met a traveller from an antique land,
lines.1: Who said—“Two vast and trunkless legs of stone
lines.2: Stand in the desert. . . . Near them, on the sand,
lines.3: Half sunk a shattered visage lies, whose frown,
lines.4: And wrinkled lip, and sneer of cold command,
lines.5: Tell that its sculptor well those passions read
lines.6: Which yet survive, stamped on these lifeless things,
lines.7: The hand that mocked them, and the heart that fed;
lines.8: And on the pedestal, these words appear:
lines.9: My name is Ozymandias, King of Kings;
lines.11: Look on my Works, ye Mighty, and despair!
lines.12: Nothing beside remains. Round the decay
lines.13: Of that colossal Wreck, boundless and bare
lines.14: The lone and level sands stretch far away.”

lines.0: Not like the brazen giant of Greek fame,
lines.1: With conquering limbs astride from land to land;
lines.2: Here at our sea-washed, sunset gates shall stand
lines.3: A mighty woman with a torch, whose flame
lines.4: Is the imprisoned lightning, and her name
lines.5: Mother of Exiles. From her beacon-hand
lines.6: Glows world-wide welcome; her mild eyes command
lines.7: The air-bridged harbor that twin cities frame.
lines.8: “Keep, ancient lands, your storied pomp!” cries she
lines.9: With silent lips. “Give me your tired, your poor,
lines.10: Your huddled masses yearning to breathe free,
lines.11: The wretched refuse of your teeming shore.
lines.12: Send these, the homeless, tempest-tost to me,
lines.13: I lift my lamp beside the golden door!”

lines.1: In the forests of the night;
lines.5: In what distant deeps or skies.
lines.6: Burnt the fire of thine eyes?
lines.7: On what wings dare he aspire?
lines.8: What the hand, dare seize the fire?
lines.11: Could twist the sinews of thy heart?
lines.12: And when thy heart began to beat,
lines.13: What dread hand? & what dread feet?
lines.15: What the hammer? what the chain,
lines.16: In what furnace was thy brain?
lines.17: What the anvil? what dread grasp,
lines.20: When the stars threw down their spears
lines.21: And water'd heaven with their tears:
lines.22: Did he smile his work to see?
lines.23: Did he who made the Lamb make thee?
lines.26: In the forests of the night:

lines.0: What needs my Shakespeare for his honoured bones,
lines.1: The labor of an age in pilèd stones,
lines.2: Or that his hallowed relics should be hid
lines.4: Dear son of Memory, great heir of fame,
lines.5: What need’st thou such weak witness of thy name?
lines.6: Thou in our wonder and astonishment
lines.7: Hast built thyself a live-long monument.
lines.8: For whilst to th’ shame of slow-endeavouring art,
lines.9: Thy easy numbers flow, and that each heart
lines.10: Hath from the leaves of thy unvalued book
lines.11: Those Delphic lines with deep impression took,
lines.12: Then thou, our fancy of itself bereaving,
lines.13: Dost make us marble with too much conceiving;
lines.14: And so sepúlchred in such pomp dost lie,
lines.15: That kings for such a tomb would wish to die.

lines.0: Tell me not, in mournful numbers,
lines.1: Life is but an empty dream!
lines.2: For the soul is dead that slumbers,
lines.3: And things are not what they seem.
lines.5: Life is real! Life is earnest!
lines.6: And the grave is not its goal;
lines.7: Dust thou art, to dust returnest,
lines.8: Was not spoken of the soul.
lines.11: Is our destined end or way;
lines.12: But to act, that each to-morrow
lines.15: Art is long, and Time is fleeting,
lines.16: And our hearts, though stout and brave,
lines.17: Still, like muffled drums, are beating
lines.20: In the world’s broad field of battle,
lines.22: Be not like dumb, driven cattle!
lines.23: Be a hero in the strife!
lines.26: Let the dead Past bury its dead!
lines.27: Act,— act in the living Present!
lines.30: Lives of great men all remind us
lines.31: We can make our lives sublime,
lines.33: Footprints on the sands of time;
lines.40: Let us, then, be up and doing,
lines.41: With a heart for any fate;
lines.43: Learn to labor and to wait.

lines.2: Through windows, and through curtains call on us?
lines.3: Must to thy motions lovers' seasons run?
lines.5: Late school boys and sour prentices
lines.6: Go tell court huntsmen that the king will ride,
lines.7: Call country ants to harvest offices,
lines.8: Love, all alike, no season knows nor clime,
lines.9: Nor hours, days, months, which are the rags of time.
lines.11: Thy beams, so reverend and strong
lines.13: I could eclipse and cloud them with a wink,
lines.14: But that I would not lose her sight so long;
lines.15: If her eyes have not blinded thine,
lines.16: Look, and tomorrow late, tell me,
lines.17: Whether both th' Indias of spice and mine
lines.18: Be where thou leftst them, or lie here with me.
lines.19: Ask for those kings whom thou saw'st yesterday,
lines.20: And thou shalt hear, All here in one bed lay.
lines.22: She's all states, and all princes, I,
lines.24: Princes do but play us; compared to this,
lines.25: All honor's mimic, all wealth alchemy.
lines.26: Thou, sun, art half as happy as we,
lines.27: In that the world's contracted thus.
lines.28: Thine age asks ease, and since thy duties be
lines.29: To warm the world, that's done in warming us.
lines.30: Shine here to us, and thou art everywhere;
lines.31: This bed thy center is, these walls, thy sphere.

lines.0: Shall I compare thee to a summer’s day?
lines.1: Thou art more lovely and more temperate:
lines.2: Rough winds do shake the darling buds of May,
lines.3: And summer’s lease hath all too short a date;
lines.4: Sometime too hot the eye of heaven shines,
lines.5: And often is his gold complexion dimm'd;
lines.6: And every fair from fair sometime declines,
lines.7: By chance or nature’s changing course untrimm'd;
lines.8: But thy eternal summer shall not fade,
lines.9: Nor lose possession of that fair thou ow’st;
lines.10: Nor shall death brag thou wander’st in his shade,
lines.11: When in eternal lines to time thou grow’st:
lines.12: So long as men can breathe or eyes can see,
lines.13: So long lives this, and this gives life to thee.

4169852f-bf8e-4f2f-8fd0-d35b3a5f12a7.title: Ode on a Grecian Urn
4169852f-bf8e-4f2f-8fd0-d35b3a5f12a7.teaser:
Thou still unravish'd bride of quietness,
Thou foster-child of silence and slow time,

edd3d445-04c8-439b-8295-addf940052db.title: Ode to a Nightingale
edd3d445-04c8-439b-8295-addf940052db.teaser:
My heart aches, and a drowsy numbness pains
My sense, as though of hemlock I had drunk,

c7b98d62-009b-4827-90a4-bd84fc352926.title: The Road Not Taken
c7b98d62-009b-4827-90a4-bd84fc352926.teaser:
Two roads diverged in a yellow wood,
And sorry I could not travel both

41e9b447-48f6-4144-8093-a0c31421bce7.teaser:
I met a traveller from an antique land,
Who said—“Two vast and trunkless legs of stone,

b27b7bf0-08dc-4d9e-8abd-10382698eb50.title: The New Colossus
b27b7bf0-08dc-4d9e-8abd-10382698eb50.teaser:
Not like the brazen giant of Greek fame,
With conquering limbs astride from land to land;

c94754ea-7236-4128-8906-1c03c3df6fac.title: The Tyger
c94754ea-7236-4128-8906-1c03c3df6fac.teaser:
Tyger Tyger, burning bright,
In the forests of the night;

cbbda901-a922-467a-8ae7-df5c63f372ad.title: On Shakespeare. 1630
cbbda901-a922-467a-8ae7-df5c63f372ad.teaser:
What needs my Shakespeare for his honoured bones,
The labor of an age in pilèd stones,

cd40ae36-2130-457b-8e6c-e3cc34d4eef2.title: A Psalm of Life
cd40ae36-2130-457b-8e6c-e3cc34d4eef2.teaser:
Tell me not, in mournful numbers,
Life is but an empty dream!

e951e7a6-cc0d-4639-8d01-66638a0675b2.title: The Sun Rising
e951e7a6-cc0d-4639-8d01-66638a0675b2.teaser:
Busy old fool, unruly sun,
Why dost thou thus,

9f91ff47-3c2d-4316-8cd8-4094f3c9c8b9.title: Sonnet 18: Shall I compare thee to a summer’s day?
9f91ff47-3c2d-4316-8cd8-4094f3c9c8b9.teaser:
Shall I compare thee to a summer’s day?
Thou art more lovely and more temperate
